newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian MinFins dip on fresh US data after rise.
newsitem.headline: Russian MinFins dip on fresh US data after rise.

text.p: Russian MinFin bonds edged down after U.S. GDP statistics renewed expectations of a possible U.S. rate hike but stayed above Tuesday's close after an early rise following U.S. Treasuries, dealers said on Wednesday.
Annualised U.S. Gross Domestic Product aUSGDP (GDP) rose 5.6 pct in the first quarter, against a forecast 4.1 percent rise and 3.8 percent rise in the fourth quarter of 1996.
The GDP price index rose 2.7 percent compared with forecast 2.1 percent rise and 1.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1996.
MinFins started to ease after the data, tracking weaker U.S. Treasury bond prices, which often show the way for MinFins.
"MinFins are falling as the figures implied not good news for Treasuries," Most Bank dealer Alexander Rodionov said.
He added prices had been rising in early trading continuing Tuesday's trend caused by first quarter employment cost index data.
Dealers said the third to seventh MinFin tranches had met resistance at 85.60, 61.00, 42.80, 48.70 and 37.60 respectively after which the opposite move started.
They added Russian banks preferred to keep flat positions ahead of Russia's and MinFin market holidays.
Russian markets are closed on May 1 and 2 for the May Day holidays followed by Victory Day on May 9. The MinFin market is closed from May 7 until May 14 due to annual coupon payment.
Further important U.S. data will be released this week, which will be closely watched for signs of inflationary pressures in the U.S. economy.
The April NAPM report comes on Thursday, and on Friday the all-important employment report for April will hit the market.
On May 20 the U.S. policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee meets and could raise U.S. interest rates.
